results.title: VFX in Thor: Ragnarok
results.brief_description: Adelaide-based VFX company Rising Sun Pictures were entrusted with a pivotal moment in Thor: Ragnaork, where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela (Cate Blanchett).

constellations_primary.name: Superhero special effects
constellations_primary.description: VFX talent isn't limited to just one studio that makes superhero blockbusters.

results.description: One of Thor: Ragnarok‘s (2017) most heartbreaking moments also happens to be one of its most beautiful. Adelaide-based visual effects company Rising Sun Pictures were entrusted with a pivotal moment where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela. The flashback plays out in artful slow motion, with the carnage captured under glittering light thanks to an innovative lighting rig designed by Satellite Lab to create high-speed changes in lighting. Rising Sun Pictures have built an international reputation for their expertise in slow motion visual effects, which were also seen in X-Men: Days of Future Past (2014).
description_for_label: One of Thor: Ragnarok‘s most heartbreaking moments is also one of its most beautiful. Adelaide-based VFX company Rising Sun Pictures created the pivotal moment where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela. The flashback happens in artful slow motion, with the carnage captured under glittering light thanks to an innovative lighting rig designed by Satellite Lab to create high-speed changes in lighting. Rising Sun Pictures also demonstrated their expertise in slow-motion VFX in X-Men: Days of Future Past.

results.title: VFX in JoJo Rabbit
results.credit_line:
VFX Supervisor: Brendan Seals
Courtesy Luma Pictures and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Taika Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit by replacing contemporary elements in scenes with period-accurate ones that represent WWII Germany.

constellations_primary.name: Undercutting extremism with absurdity
constellations_primary.description: Taika Waititi's satirical performance as Adolf Hitler in Jojo Rabbit connects to a number of other portrayals that includes ill-fated (and conceived) TV shows, memes, high camp and cinema classics.

results.description: The world through a child’s eyes is a unique thing, even more so when that child is created by Academy Award-nominee Taika Waititi. Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit. Luma Pictures took street scenes filmed in the present-day Czech Republic and made them more historically appropriate for World War II Germany. Removing contemporary elements and replacing them with period-accurate ones is subtle work, but it helps weave the tapestry of Jojo’s reality: both real and imagined.
description_for_label: The world through a child’s eyes is a unique thing, even more so when that child is created by Academy Award-nominee Taika Waititi. Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit. Luma Pictures took street scenes filmed in the present-day Czech Republic and made them more historically appropriate for World War II Germany. Removing contemporary elements and replacing them with period-accurate ones is subtle work, but it helps weave the tapestry of Jojo’s reality: both real and imagined.
results.credit_line_for_label:
VFX Supervisor: Brendan Seals
Courtesy Luma Pictures and Fox Searchlight Pictures

results.title: VFX in The Umbrella Academy
results.credit_line:
VFX Supervisor: Chris White
Courtesy Weta Digital and Netflix
results.brief_description: A look at how Weta Digital made Pogo in The Umbrella Academy.

constellations_primary.name: MoCaps and rotos
constellations_primary.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

results.description: “Nietzsche once said ‘Man is as a rope stretched between the animal and the superhuman’,” muses Sir Reginald Hargreeves in the first episode of Umbrella Academy (2019). It’s an ironic line, given the most human character in the Netflix original series is not human at all, but rather a being who personifies the middle ground between the animal and the superhuman. There are few places better suited to delicately walking that line than Weta Digital, with the New Zealand-based digital visual effects company creating the character of Pogo. Think Batman’s butler but, well, a chimpanzee. Guardian to the dysfunctional Hargreeves family of superheroes, actor Ken Hall’s movements on set became a visual reference for Weta animators, combined with the facial and vocal performance of Adam Godley in the studio.
description_for_label: “Nietzsche once said ‘Man is as a rope stretched between the animal and the superhuman’,” muses Sir Reginald Hargreeves in the Umbrella Academy. It’s ironic, given the most human character in the show isn’t human but a being who bridges the animal and the superhuman. New Zealand-based VFX studio Weta Digital drew on past experience rendering CGI apes to bring Pogo to life. Think Batman’s butler but a chimpanzee, which Weta made by combining Ken Hall’s on-set movements and Adam Godley’s facial and vocal performance.

results.title: VFX in Overwatch
results.brief_description: A look at the use of VFX in Blizzard Entertainment’s hit videogame Overwatch.

constellations_primary.name: Blizzard, Bowie and the Bonets
constellations_primary.description: Overwatch is the beginning of some surprising connections in this Constellation that explores videogame movies, cartoons, and music docos and shows.

results.description: In 2016 it seemed like Overwatch went from a game no one had heard of, to a global pop culture phenomenon overnight. Yet it’s success was about more than just the mechanics of an advanced first-person shooter. Light on narrative inside the game, players worldwide became invested in the colourful cast thanks to animated short films released as bonus content. From tragic backstories to star-crossed romances, the game’s developer Blizzard Entertainment made sure their millions of users weren’t just invested in playable avatars, they were invested in characters.
description_for_label: In 2016 it seemed like Overwatch went from a game no one had heard of, to a global pop culture phenomenon overnight. Yet it’s success was about more than just the mechanics of an advanced first-person shooter. Light on narrative inside the game, players worldwide became invested in the colourful cast thanks to animated short films released as bonus content. From tragic backstories to star-crossed romances, the game’s developer Blizzard Entertainment made sure their millions of users weren’t just invested in playable avatars, they were invested in characters.

results.title: VFX in Peter Rabbit
results.credit_line:
PR1: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™, the Movie ©2018 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
PR2: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™ 2:The Runaway, the Movie ©2021 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
results.brief_description: A look at how acclaimed VFX studio Animal Logic bought Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit to life.

constellations_primary.name: VFX to fantasy and freedom
constellations_primary.description: Founded in Sydney, and now with offices worldwide, Animal Logic are an Academy Award-winning VFX and animation studio whose job is to bring the impossible to life. And they're in good company with these other artists and filmmakers.

results.description: First springing from the mind of Beatrix Potter, Peter Rabbit is a creature that has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the beloved character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live action and animation for Peter Rabbit (2018), they used prop rabbits during the shoot so cast members had a tangible property to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.
description_for_label: Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live-action and animation for Peter Rabbit, they used prop rabbits during the shoot for cast members to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.
results.credit_line_for_label:
PETER RABBIT™ & © FW&Co. PETER RABBIT™ Movie © 2021 CPII All Rights Reserved

Special thanks to Columbia Pictures

results.title: Upside-down heads
results.brief_description: Upside down heads, which date back to around the 1700s, were one of the most popular Victorian era optical illusions, featuring on playing cards, match boxes, puzzles and in newspapers, where peacocks morphed into bearded men and royalty turned into skeletons.
results.description: Illustrators toying with perspective surprised and delighted people when they produced seemingly ordinary illustrations that revealed hidden images depending on how you look at them. Upside down heads, which date back to around the 1700s, were one of the most popular Victorian era optical illusions, featuring on playing cards, match boxes, puzzles and in newspapers, where peacocks morphed into bearded men and royalty turned into skeletons.
description_for_label: Illustrators toying with perspective surprised and delighted people when they produced seemingly ordinary illustrations that revealed hidden images depending on how you look at them. Upside down heads, which date back to around the 1700s, were one of the most popular Victorian era optical illusions, featuring on playing cards, match boxes, puzzles and in newspapers, where peacocks morphed into bearded men and royalty turned into skeletons.
